q: Which is the oldest Indo-European language text?
desc: Rigveda is considered the oldest Indo-European language text containing hymns.

q: How many hymns are there in the Rigveda?
desc: The Rigveda contains 1028 hymns divided into 10 mandalas.

q: Which Mandala of the Rigveda contains the Purushasukta hymn?
desc: The 10th Mandala of Rigveda contains the Purushasukta hymn that explains the four varnas.

q: The Gayatri Mantra is found in which Mandala of the Rigveda?
desc: The 3rd Mandala of the Rigveda contains the Gayatri Mantra, composed in praise of the Sun God.

q: Which Veda is a collection of melodies and chants?
desc: Samaveda is a collection of melodies and chants, and includes Dhrupad raga.

q: Which raga is mentioned in the Samaveda?
desc: Dhrupad is the raga associated with the Samaveda.

q: Which Veda contains hymns related to rituals and sacrifices?
desc: Yajurveda is mainly concerned with hymns and rituals/sacrifices.

q: Which Veda includes charms and spells for warding off evils?
desc: Atharvaveda includes spells and charms to ward off evils and diseases.

q: Which texts explain the hymns of the Vedas and contain ritualistic formulae?
desc: Brahmanas explain the hymns and the ritualistic meaning in the Vedas.

q: Which Brahmana is associated with the Rigveda?
desc: Kaushitaki is one of the Brahmanas associated with the Rigveda.

q: Aitareya Brahmana is linked to which Veda?
desc: Aitareya is one of the Brahmanas of the Rigveda.

q: Which Brahmana is associated with Yajurveda?
desc: Taittiriya Brahmana is linked with the Yajurveda.

q: Satapatha Brahmana is connected with which Veda?
desc: Satapatha Brahmana is another important text associated with the Yajurveda.

q: Which Brahmana belongs to the Samaveda?
desc: Jemineya is one of the Brahmanas of the Samaveda.

q: Panchvish Brahmana is related to which Veda?
desc: Panchvish Brahmana is a text connected with the Samaveda.

q: Which Brahmana is linked with Atharvaveda?
desc: Gopatha Brahmana is associated with the Atharvaveda.

q: What does the word Aranya mean?
desc: Aranya means forest, and Aranyakas are related to forest teachings.

q: Aranyakas were mainly intended for whom?
desc: Aranyakas were written for hermits and students living in the forest.

q: Which part of the Vedic literature deals with philosophical aspects of rituals?
desc: Aranyakas explore the philosophical meanings behind Vedic rituals.

q: Which Vedic text is considered a book of chants?
desc: Samaveda is often referred to as a book of chants.

q: Which Veda includes knowledge of magical spells?
desc: Atharvaveda contains spells and incantations to overcome evils.

q: Who are the four varnas mentioned in the Purushasukta?
desc: Purushasukta mentions the origin of four varnas from the cosmic being.

q: Which part of the Vedas is mainly practical in nature?
desc: Yajurveda contains practical instructions for rituals and sacrifices.

q: Which text among the following is purely musical in form?
desc: Samaveda consists of musical chants and is considered the root of Indian classical music.

q: What is the main focus of Brahmana texts?
desc: Brahmanas focus on the ritualistic aspect of Vedic hymns.

q: Who were the primary audience of Aranyakas?
desc: Aranyakas were designed for hermits and students practicing ascetic life.

q: Which Veda is associated with the Sun God through the Gayatri Mantra?
desc: The Gayatri Mantra found in the Rigveda is composed in praise of the Sun God.

q: Which Veda contains the Purushasukta?
desc: Purushasukta, explaining the creation of varnas, is in the 10th Mandala of Rigveda.

q: Which of these is not a Veda?
desc: Vedanta is a philosophical system, not one of the four Vedas.

q: Which Vedic text is known for its magical content?
desc: Atharvaveda contains magic, charms, and incantations for practical life.

q: Which Vedic text discusses social and religious meanings of rituals?
desc: The Brahmanas explain the social and religious significance of Vedic rituals.

q: What is the literal meaning of 'Aranyakas'?
desc: Aranyakas means 'forest texts', meant for forest-dwelling hermits and students.

q: The Gopatha Brahmana is associated with which Veda?
desc: Gopatha is the only Brahmana text related to the Atharvaveda.

q: Which part of the Vedic literature is closest to Indian classical music?
desc: Samaveda forms the foundation of Indian classical music with its melodic chants.

q: How many Mandalas are there in the Rigveda?
desc: The Rigveda is divided into 10 Mandalas (books).

q: Which Mandala contains hymns praising the Sun God?
desc: The 3rd Mandala includes the Gayatri Mantra, dedicated to the Sun God.

q: Which part of Vedic literature transitions into philosophical discussion?
desc: Aranyakas mark the transition from ritualistic to philosophical aspects.

q: Which text explains the concept of creation through the cosmic being?
desc: Purushasukta describes the creation of the universe and the varna system.

q: Which part of the Vedas focuses on practical application in rituals?
desc: Yajurveda serves as a practical guide for conducting Vedic rituals.

q: Which Brahmana is considered the most voluminous?
desc: Satapatha Brahmana is the most detailed and voluminous of the Brahmana texts.

q: Which Veda was primarily recited during Soma sacrifices?
desc: Samaveda was sung by priests during Soma sacrifices in rituals.

q: Which is the most recent among the four Vedas?
desc: Atharvaveda is considered the last of the four Vedas to be composed.

q: Which Vedic text includes spells for healing diseases?
desc: Atharvaveda contains spells and charms, including those for healing diseases.

q: What is the primary purpose of the Brahmanas?
desc: Brahmanas provide explanations and procedures for rituals mentioned in the Vedas.

q: Which Brahmana is common to both white and black Yajurveda branches?
desc: Satapatha is associated with the Shukla (white) Yajurveda but also studied in Krishna (black) traditions.

q: Which Veda is most commonly associated with mantras used in yajnas?
desc: Yajurveda is a compilation of ritual formulas recited during yajnas (sacrifices).

q: Which Vedic division includes explanations rather than original hymns?
desc: Brahmanas are prose texts that explain Vedic hymns and rituals.

q: Which Aranyaka text is associated with the Rigveda?
desc: Aitareya Aranyaka is associated with the Rigveda and includes philosophical interpretations.

q: Which part of Vedic literature serves as a link between rituals and philosophy?
desc: Aranyakas bridge the gap between the ritualistic Brahmanas and the philosophical Upanishads.

q: The term 'Samhita' in Vedic literature refers to?
desc: Samhita refers to the collection of mantras or hymns in each Veda.

q: What are the Upanishads primarily focused on?
desc: The Upanishads emphasize philosophical concepts like right belief and knowledge, and they criticize rituals and sacrifices.

q: How many Upanishads are there in total?
desc: There are 108 Upanishads, which are considered philosophical texts in Indian tradition.

q: Which is the oldest Upanishad?
desc: The Brihadaranyaka is considered the oldest of all the Upanishads.

q: What is another name for the Upanishads?
desc: The Upanishads are also known as Vedanta, meaning 'end of the Vedas'.

q: What do the Smritis explain?
desc: Smritis explain the rules and regulations in Vedic life.

q: Which is the first law book among the Smritis?
desc: Manusmriti is regarded as the first law book among the Smritis.

q: Which of the following is NOT a part of the Smritis?
desc: Matsya Purana is a Purana, not a Smriti text.

q: How many Vedangas are there?
desc: There are six Vedangas, which are considered limbs of the Vedas.

q: Which Vedanga deals with pronunciation?
desc: Shiksha is the Vedanga concerned with pronunciation.

q: Which Vedanga is related to rituals?
desc: Kalpa deals with rituals and ceremonial procedures in Vedic tradition.

q: Which Vedanga covers grammar?
desc: Vyakaran is the Vedanga that covers grammar rules.

q: Which Vedanga deals with etymology?
desc: Nikrukta is the Vedanga focused on etymology.

q: Which Vedanga is concerned with metrics?
desc: Chhanda deals with the meter or rhythm of Vedic hymns.

q: What does the Vedanga Jyotish focus on?
desc: Jyotish is the Vedanga that deals with astronomy and astrology.

q: What are the Vedangas collectively referred to as?
desc: Vedangas are considered the six auxiliary disciplines or 'limbs' of the Vedas.

q: Which text type deals with world creation and genealogies?
desc: Puranas deal with the creation of the world, genealogies of gods and sages, and royal dynasties.

q: How many famous Puranas are there?
desc: There are 18 major or famous Puranas in Hindu literature.

q: Which is the oldest Puranic text?
desc: The Matsya Purana is considered the oldest among the Puranic texts.

q: Which category of text criticizes rituals and sacrifices?
desc: The Upanishads criticize excessive rituals and sacrifices, focusing instead on spiritual knowledge.

q: Which Smriti is attributed to sage Yajnavalkya?
desc: Yajnavalkya-smriti is a legal and dharma text attributed to the sage Yajnavalkya.

q: Which category of texts is also known as 'Vedanta'?
desc: The Upanishads are also called Vedanta, meaning they form the concluding part of the Vedic literature.

q: Which text is not part of the Vedangas?
desc: Manusmriti is a Smriti, not a Vedanga.

q: What is the focus of Parasharasmriti?
desc: Parasharasmriti is a Smriti that deals with laws and ethical conduct.

q: Which of these texts forms part of the Puranas?
desc: Matsya Purana is one of the 18 major Puranas.

q: Which category of texts deals with royal dynasties and rishis?
desc: Puranas describe the genealogies of gods, sages, and kings.

q: Which Vedanga would help a priest learn proper chanting?
desc: Shiksha teaches the correct pronunciation and intonation for Vedic chants.

q: Who is the author of Naradasmriti?
desc: Naradasmriti is attributed to the sage Narada.

q: What does the term 'Smriti' literally mean?
desc: Smriti means 'that which is remembered', as opposed to Shruti (heard).

q: Which Smriti is associated with legal matters and court procedures?
desc: Naradasmriti is known for its emphasis on legal codes and court procedures.

q: What does the Purana literature focus on besides creation?
desc: Besides creation, Puranas detail the genealogies of gods, sages, and kings.

q: What do the Puranas primarily deal with?
desc: The Puranas focus on world creation, genealogies of gods and sages, and royal dynasties.

q: How many famous Puranas are there?
desc: There are 18 well-known Puranas in Hindu literature.

q: Which is considered the oldest Puranic text?
desc: Matsya Purana is regarded as the oldest among the Puranas.

q: What does the term 'Darshana' refer to in Indian philosophy?
desc: 'Darshana' refers to the six classical schools of Indian philosophy.

q: Who is associated with Nyaya Darshana?
desc: Gautam is credited with founding the Nyaya school of philosophy.

q: Which sage is linked to the Vaishesika school of philosophy?
desc: Kanada is known for establishing the Vaishesika Darshana.

q: Kapila is the founder of which philosophical school?
desc: Kapila founded the Sankhya Darshana, a dualistic philosophical system.

q: Patanjali is best known for which Darshana?
desc: Patanjali is famous for his work on the Yoga Darshana.

q: Jaimini is credited with founding which Darshana?
desc: Jaimini authored the Purva Mimansa philosophy focusing on rituals.

q: Who is the founder of Uttara Mimansa (Vedanta)?
desc: Vyasa, also known as Badrayana, is credited with the Uttara Mimansa or Vedanta.

q: How many Upavedas are there?
desc: There are four Upavedas associated with the four Vedas.

q: Which Upaveda deals with the art of warfare?
desc: Dhanurveda is the Upaveda related to the art of warfare.

q: Dhanurveda is the Upaveda of which Veda?
desc: Dhanurveda is associated with the Yajurveda.

q: Which Upaveda is related to art and music?
desc: Gandharvaveda deals with performing arts like music and dance.

q: Gandharvaveda is an Upaveda of which Veda?
desc: Samaveda is associated with Gandharvaveda.

q: Which Upaveda focuses on architecture?
desc: Shilpaveda is concerned with architecture and craftsmanship.

q: Which Veda is associated with Shilpaveda?
desc: Atharvaveda is the Veda linked with Shilpaveda.

q: Which Upaveda deals with medicine?
desc: Ayurveda is the ancient Indian system of medicine.

q: Ayurveda is the Upaveda of which Veda?
desc: Rigveda is associated with the Upaveda Ayurveda.

q: Who is the author of Mahabharata?
desc: Vyasa composed the epic Mahabharata.

q: What is another name for the Mahabharata?
desc: Mahabharata is also called Jaya Samhita and Satasahasri Samhita.

q: Approximately how many verses are in the Mahabharata?
desc: The Mahabharata contains around 100,000 verses.

q: Who authored the Ramayana?
desc: The sage Valmiki wrote the Ramayana.

q: How many verses are there in the Ramayana approximately?
desc: The Ramayana has about 29,000 verses.

q: Which epic is older than the Ramayana?
desc: The Mahabharata predates the Ramayana.

q: Which Darshana is also called Vedanta?
desc: Uttara Mimansa is also known as Vedanta.

q: Which Darshana emphasizes ritual action and dharma?
desc: Purva Mimansa focuses on rituals and dharma.

q: What is the main subject of Ayurveda?
desc: Ayurveda deals with the science of health and healing.

q: Which text is known as Satasahasri Samhita?
desc: Mahabharata is also called Satasahasri Samhita due to its 100,000 verses.

q: What was the capital of Gandhara Mahajanapada?
desc: Gandhara was located between Kabul and Rawalpindi and had Taxila as its capital.

q: Which Mahajanapada had Champa as its capital?
desc: Anga, located in Bhagalpur and Munger in Bihar, had Champa as its capital.

q: Magadha under Ashoka had which capital?
desc: During Ashoka's reign, Magadha's capital was Patliputra.

q: Which city was the capital of Kashi?
desc: Kashi, located in present-day Varanasi district, had Varanasi as its capital.

q: Where was the capital of Vajji Mahajanapada?
desc: Vajji was located in the Vaishali district of UP and had Vaishali as its capital.

q: Which Mahajanapada had Kusinagara and Pava as capitals?
desc: Malla, located south of Vaishali, had Kusinagara and Pava as its capitals.

q: Sothivati-nagar or Shuktimati was the capital of which Mahajanapada?
desc: Chedi was situated near the River Ken in the Bundelkhand area and had Sothivati-nagar or Shuktimati as its capital.

q: Which Mahajanapada had Kaushambi as its capital?
desc: Vatsa, located along the River Yamuna and present-day Allahabad and Mirzapur, had Kaushambi as its capital.

q: Kosala's capital was?
desc: Kosala, located in Eastern UP, had Sravasti and Ayodhya (Saket) as its capitals.

q: Which Mahajanapada had Hastinapur and Indraprastha as its capitals?
desc: Kuru was based in the Ganga-Yamuna doab (Delhi-Meerut region) and had Hastinapur and Indraprastha as capitals.

q: Which Mahajanapada had Achichhatra and Kampilya as capitals?
desc: Panchala, located in the Ganga-Yamuna doab (Rohilkhand), had Achichhatra and Kampilya as its capitals.

q: Viratnagar was the capital of which Mahajanapada?
desc: Matsya, situated in the Jaipur-Bharatpur-Alwar district, had Viratnagar/Bairath as its capital.

q: Mathura was the capital of which Mahajanapada?
desc: Surasenas, located in the Mathura region, had Mathura as its capital.

q: Asmaka was located near which river?
desc: Asmaka was located near the River Godavari in present-day Maharashtra.

q: Which Mahajanapada had Patna or Patali as its capital?
desc: Asmaka, located near Paithan in Maharashtra, had Patna or Patali as its capital.

q: Which Mahajanapada had Ujjain and Mahismati as capitals?
desc: Avanti (in Malwa region) had Ujjain (northern capital) and Mahismati (southern capital).

q: Kamboja was located in which present-day area?
desc: Kamboja was located in the Hazara district of present-day Pakistan.

q: Rajapur or Hataka was the capital of which Mahajanapada?
desc: Kamboja had Rajapur or Hataka as its capital.

q: Which of the following had Vaishali as a capital?
desc: Vaishali was a capital of both Vajji and Magadha (during Shishunaga’s time).

q: Which Mahajanapada had multiple capitals over time like Girivraj, Rajagriha, and Patliputra?
desc: Magadha evolved through multiple capitals including Girivraj, Rajagriha, Vaishali, and Patliputra.
